definitions.definition: a number of people standing or sitting next to each other in a line; a number of objects arranged in a line
definitions.sensetop: row of somebody/somethingin a rowrow upon row of somebody/something

examples.text: There is a row of trees in front of the house.
We sat in a row at the back of the room.
The vegetables were planted in neat rows.
He looked down at row upon row of eager faces.
She arranged the chairs in two neat rows.
The children stood in a row.
endless rows of identical houses

definitions.definition: a line of seats in a cinema, theatre, etc.

examples.text: Let's sit in the back row.
We have seats in the front row.
Our seats are five rows from the front.

definitions.definition: a line of numbers or words arranged one after the other across the page in a table

examples.text: The top row of Table 2 shows the current values.
There are eight rows and four columns in the table.
You can insert rows between existing ones.

definitions.definition: a complete line of stitches in knitting or crochet (= ways of making clothing, etc. out of wool)
used in the name of some roads

examples.text: Manor Row
I live at 22 Western Row.

definitions.definition: an act of rowing a boat; the period of time spent doing this

examples.text: We went for a row on the lake.

definitions.definition: to have made all the preparations needed to do something; to be well organized

examples.text: The company has its ducks in a row for a move into the Asian market.
Get your ducks in a row before you retire.

definitions.definition: if something happens several times in a row, it happens in exactly the same way each time, and nothing different happens in the time between

examples.text: This is her third win in a row.

definitions.definition: if something happens for several days, etc. in a row, it happens on each of those days

examples.text: Inflation has fallen for the third month in a row.
It rained for five days in a row.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 4 Old English rāw, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch rij and German Reihe. noun sense 5 Old English rōwan, of Germanic origin; related to rudder; from an Indo-European root shared by Latin remus ‘oar’, Greek eretmon ‘oar’.
